data.title: Cheat Solving
data.solution:
import Data.Char (isAlpha)
import Data.Maybe (fromJust)
import Data.List (sort)

-- this paragraph only for test case validation
import Debug.Trace
import Control.Monad (join)
import Data.List (group)
restickerable = (== replicate 6 9) . join traceShow . map length . drop 2 . group . sort

-- real solution starts here
main = interact $ format . solvable . readCube

readCube s | restickerable s = zip (words pattern) (filter isAlpha s)
pattern = "             ULB UB UBR                         \
          \             UL   U UR                          \
          \             UFL UF URF                         \
          \                                                \
          \ LBU LU LUF  FLU FU FUR  RFU RU RUB  BRU BU BUL \
          \ LB   L LF   FL   F FR   RF   R RB   BR   B BL  \ 
          \ LDB LD LFD  FDL FD FRD  RDF RD RBD  BDR BD BLD \
          \                                                \
          \             DLF DF DFR                         \
          \             DL   D DR                          \
          \             DBL DB DRB                         "

solvable cb = ps == sort (map (pieceAt cb) ps) where ps = sort (map fst cb)
pieceAt cb p = map (fromJust . flip lookup cb) (rotations p)
rotations s = take (length s) (iterate rotate s)
rotate s = tail s ++ [head s]

format True = "SOLVABLE"
format False = "UNSOLVABLE"
data.statement:
Can a Rubik's cube be solved by Reassembly™?

A popular method to solve a Rubik's cube when you don't know any algorithms is to disassemble it and reassemble it directly into a solved state.  It doesn't damage the stickers and is guaranteed to always work... provided the stickers haven't been messed with, that is!

Seung-Hyuk had left his cube solved on the table, but when he came back from his break a few minutes later, he noticed that his cube was now scrambled, and there was an evil grin on Hyo-Min's face.  Obviously Hyo-Min had scrambled it, but had he been moving stickers around as well, rendering it unsolvable using the Reassembly™ method?  Help Seung-Hyuk by telling him whether or not he can disassemble the pieces and assemble them back together into a solved cube state.

You are given a cube state in pattern format. A solved cube looks like this:
`
    UUU
    UUU
    UUU

LLL FFF RRR BBB
LLL FFF RRR BBB
LLL FFF RRR BBB

    DDD
    DDD
    DDD
`
Letters {{ULFRBD}} mean “this sticker belongs on the Up/‌Left/‌Front/‌Right/‌Back/‌Down face”.

A cube with an edge flip or a corner twist is obviously solvable using the Reassembly™ method: simply pop the piece out and insert it back with the correct orientation.

A cube where a corner has two stickers exchanged out of three cannot be solved using the Reassembly™ method: there is no way that corner can be placed where it has more than one sticker on the right face. Similarly, any piece with two stickers of the same color would render the cube unsolvable, as there is no reassembly that would put those two stickers back on the same face.

A cube where any regular disassembly-free scramble has been applied is obviously solvable using the Reassembly™ method. One is given in example below.

testCases.title: L2 D R′ D′ F′ D′ R D′ R2 F2
testCases.testIn:
DUD
    DUU
    BDL

LLL UFF ULR FBF
LLR BFF URB DBF
FRD BUU BFB DBR

    LRR
    DDR
    ULR

testCases.title: Slice Moves
testCases.testIn:
UDU
    DUD
    UDU

LRL FBF RLR BFB
RLR BFB LRL FBF
LRL FBF RLR BFB

    DUD
    UDU
    DUD

testCases.title: UF flip, URF twist on y2
testCases.testIn:
UUU
    UUU
    UBB

RRR BUL ULL FFF
RRR BBB LLL FFF
RRR BBB LLL FFF

    DDD
    DDD
    DDD

testCases.title: Edge Flip and Corner Twist
testCases.testIn:
UUU
    UUU
    UFF

LLL FUR URR BBB
LLL FFF RRR BBB
LLL FFF RRR BBB

    DDD
    DDD
    DDD

testCases.title: Edge case 1
testCases.testIn:
UFU
    UUU
    UUU

LLL FUF RRR BBB
LLL FFF RRR BBB
LLL FFF RRR BBB

    DDD
    DDD
    DDD

testCases.title: Edge case 1
testCases.testIn:
DFD
    DUU
    BDL

LLL UFF ULR FBF
LLR BFU URB DBF
FRD BUU BFB DBR

    LRR
    DDR
    ULR

testCases.title: Edge case 2
testCases.testIn:
UUU
    UUU
    UUU

LLL FDF RRR BBB
LLL FFF RRR BBB
LFL FFF RRR BBB

    DDD
    LDD
    DDD

testCases.title: Edge case 2
testCases.testIn:
DUD
    LUU
    BDL

LFL UFF ULR FBF
LLR BFD URB DBF
FRD BUU BFB DBR

    LRR
    DDR
    ULR

testCases.title: Corner case 1
testCases.testIn:
UUU
    UUU
    UUU

LLL FFR FRR BBB
LLL FFF RRR BBB
LLL FFF RRR BBB

    DDD
    DDD
    DDD

testCases.title: Corner case 1
testCases.testIn:
DUD
    DUU
    BDL

LLL UFF ULR FBF
LLR BFF URB DBF
RRD BUU BFB DBF

testCases.title: Corner case 2

    UUU

LLL FFF URR BBB

testCases.title: Corner case 2
testCases.testIn:

    FUD
    RFD

FUR BRR FBR DBL
RLB UFL DRL BBD
ULF DLL BRL DDU

    LFU
    UDU
    FFB

testCases.title: Corner case 3

UUU
    UUU
    UUU

LLL FFF DRR BBB
LLL FFF RRR BBB
LLL FFF RRR BBB

    RDD
    DDD
    DDD

testCases.title: Corner case 3

RUD

    BDL

LLL UFF ULR FBF
LLR BFF URB DBF
FRD BUU BFB DBD

    BUU
    BBF

FLU RRU LLD FBR
ULL FFD LRR UBF
RFB URB LDR FDD

testCases.testIn:
URB
    FUD
    UFD

FUR BRR FBR DBL
RLB UFL DRL BBD
RLF DLL BRL DDU

    LFU
    UDU
    FFB

testCases.title: Sticker Salad
testCases.testIn:
BRD
    DFR
    RBD

ULF LRB DBD LLB
RLL BUU BFD FFU
BDR URL UDF RFL

    FBU
    LRU
    DFU

testCases.title: Other Sticker Salad
testCases.testIn:
UFD
    URB
    UBF

LFR FDU LRU RDB
UFF DFB UUB LLR
BLL DBD BRL FLU

    DBR
    RFD
    DRL

data.constraints:
Apart from the stickering, all cubes are standard 3×3×3 Rubik's cubes.
Only valid sticker colors are provided.
No extra stickers have been used — all cubes here could be solved using the Restickering™ method.

A cube is made of:
* 6 unisticker center pieces
* 12 bisticker edge pieces
* 8 tristicker corner pieces
In this problem's context, you can assume center caps can be exchanged freely.
data.outputDescription:
{{SOLVABLE}} if it is possible to disassemble the cube and assemble it back in a solved state.
{{UNSOLVABLE}} otherwise.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Can a Rubik's cube be solved by Reassembly™?

A popular method to solve a Rubik's cube when you don't know any algorithms is to disassemble it and reassemble it directly into a solved state. It doesn't damage the stickers and is guaranteed to always work... provided the stickers haven't been messed with, that is!

Seung-Hyuk had left his cube solved on the table, but when he came back from his break a few minutes later, he noticed that his cube was now scrambled, and there was an evil grin on Hyo-Min's face. Obviously Hyo-Min had scrambled it, but had he been moving stickers around as well, rendering it unsolvable using the Reassembly™ method? Help Seung-Hyuk by telling him whether or not he can disassemble the pieces and assemble them back together into a solved cube state.

You are given a cube state in pattern format. A solved cube looks like this:

    UUU
    UUU
    UUU

LLL FFF RRR BBB
LLL FFF RRR BBB
LLL FFF RRR BBB

    DDD
    DDD
    DDD

Letters ULFRBD mean “this sticker belongs on the Up/‌Left/‌Front/‌Right/‌Back/‌Down face”.

A cube with an edge flip or a corner twist is obviously solvable using the Reassembly™ method: simply pop the piece out and insert it back with the correct orientation.

A cube where a corner has two stickers exchanged out of three cannot be solved using the Reassembly™ method: there is no way that corner can be placed where it has more than one sticker on the right face. Similarly, any piece with two stickers of the same color would render the cube unsolvable, as there is no reassembly that would put those two stickers back on the same face.

A cube where any regular disassembly-free scramble has been applied is obviously solvable using the Reassembly™ method. One is given in example below.
Input
11 lines (including 2 blank): a cube pattern
Output
SOLVABLE if it is possible to disassemble the cube and assemble it back in a solved state.
UNSOLVABLE otherwise.
Constraints
Apart from the stickering, all cubes are standard 3×3×3 Rubik's cubes.
Only valid sticker colors are provided.
No extra stickers have been used — all cubes here could be solved using the Restickering™ method.

A cube is made of:
* 6 unisticker center pieces
* 12 bisticker edge pieces
* 8 tristicker corner pieces
In this problem's context, you can assume center caps can be exchanged freely.
Example
Input
    DUD
    DUU
    BDL

LLL UFF ULR FBF
LLR BFF URB DBF
FRD BUU BFB DBR

    LRR
    DDR
    ULR
Output
SOLVABLE
